Text.Text: Hmm.  Yes... yes?  Behind the fireplace?  Ah, but silence... it seems the living have come.

Ah, but it is *soldiers* you seek, yes?  If so, then your steps have led you false... for I, I am merely one who sweeps up after death has had its day, not the one who fills his kingdom.  If you are in need of blades, seek them elsewhere.
This row of vessels here, mayhap, lined up like ships?  They have passed on, yes, they have sailed through this life and into the keeping of Old Lord Skull... heh.  But their spirits echo still.
Yes, heh, the Lord of the Dead... my Lord... Myrkul is his name, and the road to his Bone Castle is the road we all walk... it is the way of such things.

When the goblins struck, they brought the first of many deaths...  these that lie here are but fingerbones of the skeleton of the battle.  Of the two halves, Targos and the Horde, neither was spared, and in death, the halves have become wh-
Hmnn?  Yes... but your battles are over now, soldier of Targos, and, no, there is nothing to be done.  Now *rest.*
Silence, spirit!  The living walk among us, and to you, dead one... I may speak at any time, yes.
One who can speak to the dead has value on the field of battle.  This goblin here... it was Ulbrec's wish that I speak to him and learn what secrets he holds in his head...  but that is not all, no.
It still lives out its last moments, yes, but the vessel is a frightened, gibbering thing... and out of my keeping.   There are no secrets of value to be mined from his skull, no.

No... listening, perhaps.  There is no novelty in such things, if that thought is on your mind.  The speech of the dead is... wearisome.  They ask, demand, call, scream for attention... they rattle on like childr-
And this goblin here - it still lives out its last moments, yes, a frightened, gibbering thing... howling at the moment of its death.

The dead are in need of proper burial, and such rites are best performed by a priest of death.  The... priests of Tempus have no skill in such matters - they praise the fallen in the name of battle, but such things do not let the spirits rest quietly, no.
I have found that wherever Tempus claims to rule, it is only from Myrkul's shadow that he dwells.  The face of Myrkul is the last vision of all soldiers - even Tempus knows this.
I travel where death does, I shadow my Lord's footsteps.  He has... touched Targos, and soon, I think, yes, soon, He will walk amongst the living of Targos. The wind smells of such things.
I came with brothers... the Iron Collar mercenaries, my brothers.  We have come some distance.  But that is not why *I* have come, no.
In the days to come, all of Targos will serve Myrkul.  All of them worship Myrkul, whether they know it or not, and all of them shall come before him.

By word, perhaps not, by obeisance, perhaps not, but by your deeds to come, I think, yes, you will be, especially if I judge that those weapons you carry are intended to shed blood in the battles to come.
If you have ever caused the death of another, you dwell in Myrkul's shadow. Even in dying, you serve Myrkul and strengthen his kingdom. Thus, his worshippers and followers are everywhere.
It would please me to entertain the questions of the living... a while longer, yes.

Your words are choked in cobwebs of ignorance - no, inexperience only... and there is no harm in brushing such things away.  Know that the dead must be silenced as they are laid to rest, yes, and care must be taken so that enemies cannot raise them up again to dance in the armies of our foe.

And sometimes... sometimes, yes... the dead must be *spoken* to one last time to yield their secrets before they are sunk beneath the ground - every military commander knows this, and this Ulbrec... this Lord Ulbrec... is a clever man.  He knows my value, and I carry his coin to prove it.
I had a room at the Inn, I did, but... there are spirits there that will not be silenced, no, and I am in need of rest.

I heard a spirit weeping in the Inn, yes, in the room with the window, the window that was broken long ago.  If I had a poetical bent, when night falls, she rises like the tide, and the tears flow from her wounded heart.
But because I detest poetry, I will simply say that ghosts, more so than other spirits, are a... tiresome bunch.
They tend to... *dwell* on things, yes, and howl on about it, like dogs outside your window when you are trying to sleep.  So did I leave the Inn?  Of course - for I could not remain.

Who knows?  And if there is no gold to be had in knowing, why should one care?  Heed me - ghosts sob and carry on about omens and portents, but in truth, they are only clamoring for attention so someone will respect their grief, yes.  Death... does little for their manners... or their etiquette.
How is it you have lived, yet know nothing of learning a woman's secrets?  If you would know her heart, then go to her at night.  Yes, nighttime is best, I think.
This is no inn for the living, nor would you wish to stay here when night falls.  Go to the one who holds claim to the Weeping Widow - he can wake you at the appointed hour.
But you and this woman stem from the same flesh - come now, you know how one learns a woman's secrets.  If you would know her heart, then go to her at night.  Yes, nighttime is best, I think.
Old Lord Skull *always* comes sooner than one thinks, yes - you are wise to say so, and I would ask you to forgive my words, yes?
The Iron Collar band, yes, we stem from Cormyr.  Had to leave, yes, twice.

Cormyr... hmm... Cormyrians take a more... primitive view toward their dead.  And the possessions of the dead.  They feel that all that is buried with the dead should remain with the dead.  A foolish notion.
Heh... no, did they?  They must have been drinking their way to Myrkul's door - no, there is no thievery when the dead give permission.
Come now - once one has walked through Myrkul's gate, such things as robbery... blur.  Besides, there is no thievery when the dead give permission.
Be silent!  Yes, *permission* to relieve them of their funeral trappings... what use have the dead for trinkets and baubles?  Where is the harm in that?
Only a *few* of the restless dead cling to some object of importance to them, especially the greed-driven or those that hunger, such as the wights of the barrow and the tunneling ghouls.

It is why their touch pains the living, yes, holds them fast.  With the dead of these types, it is ofttimes better to barter with them than meet them with iron, no matter what its bent or enchantment.

Phaen?  Ah, yes, Phaen.  We met him in Luskan.  He serves other interests, but takes Targos' coin.  He is death's friend in this place.  He hired us, Geoffrey, Kickshaw, and Blanchard, to escort him here, and we have done that, and now the rest suckle on Targos' breast, drawing gold from goblin fear.  Foolishness.
Oh, yes - watch that one.  He stays in the makeshift barracks, just north of the Town Hall.  If you speak to him, keep your sword close.  His loyalties are... peculiar ones.
To you, perhaps, yes - but to I, I wear my loyalty for all to see.  I do not hide it - nor do I change it when gold is placed in my palm, like a sell-sword does.
Shhhh, all of you!  Silence!  Now... let us see what brings the living again before us?  Heh... it is not your time, I think.
Hmn... I fear to tell you what I have learned... which is to say, precious little, yes.
The goblin tongue is not one familiar to me, and making sense of its words has been, hmm... difficult, yes.
Very well... I shall inscribe the words for you, yes, and I shall have it sent to Crawford, yes.
Very well... it keeps repeating the phrase, "Vaws-hak..."
Then it speaks of "Uhj - kellor... vazsedrae..."
Hmmm... "Caballus - unt -unjtor, vazedrae..."
Hmmm... "Irter - Caballus - Ghotrag - Vghotan, vazedrae - julik."
"Kherk-nor... Aseidez-ki," hmmm... and that word, "julik," again, yes.
Then the thing falls silent - nothing more issues from its dead lips, no, nothing.  Hmm.
That last phrase, no?  What does it mean?
As always, I am pleased to be of service when the coins are forthcoming, yes.
Hmn?  The man, the townsman?  Yes, well, hmmm.  This is his home, it is.  I thought he should be returned here.  Set him at peace, yes.
Eh, hmmm, yes.
Eh, but what use would he have for such possessions, if I were to ask him of such things?  The dead cannot benefit from such things...

But your mind is sharp, yes, I asked him of such things.  Behind the fireplace, he said, in a narrow crack in the wall, that is where his gold lies sleeping.  Take it, it is yours, we shall say no more of it.
Eh, yes, of course.  Lord Ulbrec's coin is enough for me, yes, no more will I question the dead of such matters.
Eh, hmmm... as payment for your silence, yes, one of the dead spoke of a treasure buried beneath a floor board of one of the ruined buildings in Targos... but I know not which one.
No, no... I paid him well, I did.  I inscribed a protective glyph over the room with the weeping spirit, and I gave him a magic potion... no, he was well paid.
I... hmmm.  You know... little of Myrkul's teaching - I will not debate such things with you, no.  In any event, the potion I gave to the innkeeper paid for my rooms many times over, yes.
Yes, yes, it - eh, what?  What is it you said of the bottle?
The bottle is ghost-touched?  But... hmmm.
Hmm.  Yes.  Quite useful, such a thing.  Heh, it seems I was... over-generous in my gift.  The innkeeper may keep it - with my good graces.

Take it to the spirit in the weeping widow, if she remains.  Put one of her tears inside, and you may use it in enchantments - ask Ulbrec's wife, the elven woman enchantress - she knows of such things.
It is not for me to say - I will only say that it is more than enough to pay for my rooms at the inn, yes.
There is an attack upon Targos - every hand is needed at the docks to repel the goblins.
Who are you?  What are these bodies doing here?
Are you Koluhm?  Shawford Crale sent me to find you.  These people here... are they dead?
Who are you?  What are all these bodies doing here?
Old Lord Skull?
Old Lord Skull?  Myrkul, Lord of the Dead?
What happened to these people?
What is that goblin doing here?
Forget it, Koluhm.  I had some other questions for you.
I must take my leave.  Farewell.
What happened to these people?
What is that goblin doing here?
Did that corpse just -
Are you *talking* to that corpse?
What do you mean?
I... see.  Are you *talking* to that corpse?
But what are you doing here?  And why are these bodies here?
I warn you, priest, when you speak of Tempus, be mindful of where your words fall.
Is this why you came to Targos?
Tempus is whom I serve, and I have little patience for your blasphemy.
The Ilmatari deliver the suffering from pain - we do not deliver others to the gates of your god, and we do *not* worship him.
Perhaps the dawn will bring you to see the error in your words, Myrkulyte - the Morninglords of Lathander do not worship your god.
The Silverstars of Selune see much in the moon's light, Myrkulyte, but I see little truth in your words - neither I, nor others of my order, worship your god.
The Watchers of Helm have little patience for such blasphemy, Myrkulyte... we do *not* worship your god.
Perhaps you would benefit by reading more of the teachings of Oghma, Myrkulyte - the Lorekeepers of Oghma do not worship your god.
I will not warn you again, Myrkulyte - if you persist, I will send you to your god.  The Battleguards of Tempus do *not* worship Myrkul.
Do not speak such blasphemy before a Dreadmaster, Myrkulyte... Bane does not deal lightly with profaners, and we do *not* worship your god.
I think Mask would take... exception to your claim, Myrkulyte.  We Demarchs do not worship the Lord of Bones.
Watch your blasphemy, Myrkulyte.  The Stormlords fill Myrkul's kingdom, but Talos does *not* worship your god.
You include us as being Myrkul worshippers?  I think you are mistaken.
We have no traffic with the God of the Dead, priest.  Watch your words.
I think we have spoken long enough.  Farewell.
Shawford Crale has sent us here to see what you have learned from this goblin's corpse.
Why were you even allowed within the city walls?
Do you actually... rest here?
Cahl-Hyred, the innkeeper, said you left the inn without paying.
Can you tell us what the potion you gave to Cahl-Hyred is?
Can you tell us anything about the spirit that haunts the Weeping Widow Inn?
The Iron Collar mercenary band said you were staying at the Weeping Widow Inn... why are you here?
Who are these Iron Collar mercenaries you speak of?
So you said you traveled here with the Iron Collar mercenary band?
Do you know someone named Phaen?
Do you know someone named Phaen?
Do you know someone named Phaen?
I think we have spoken long enough.  Farewell.
Shawford Crale has sent us here to see what you have learned from this goblin's corpse.
Why were you even allowed within the city walls?
Do you actually... rest here?
Cahl-Hyred, the innkeeper, said you left the inn without paying.
Can you tell us what the potion you gave to Cahl-Hyred is?
Can you tell us anything about the spirit that haunts the Weeping Widow Inn?
The Iron Collar mercenary band said you were staying at the Weeping Widow Inn... why are you here?
Who are these Iron Collar mercenaries you speak of?
So you said you traveled here with the Iron Collar mercenary band?
Do you know someone named Phaen?
Do you know someone named Phaen?
Do you know someone named Phaen?
I think we have spoken long enough.  Farewell.
Hmm.  I have other questions I would ask you.
I have heard enough.  Farewell.
What do you mean?
Hmm.  I have other questions I would ask you.
I have heard enough.  Farewell.
Why does she weep?
How could we speak to her?
How could we speak to her?
Hmm.  I have other questions I would ask you.
I have heard enough.  Farewell.
How could we speak to her?
How could we speak to her?
Hmm.  I have other questions I would ask you.
I have heard enough.  Farewell.
Hmm.  Can we rest here until night falls?
Hmm.  I have other questions I would ask you.
I have heard enough.  Farewell.
Hmm.  I have other questions I would ask you.
I have heard enough.  Farewell.
If you ever come to *me* at night, you'll be joining Old Lord Skull sooner than you think.
Would you mind if we rested here until night falls?
Hmm.  I have other questions I would ask you.
I have heard enough.  Farewell.
Would you mind if we rested here until night falls?
Hmm.  I have other questions I would ask you.
I have heard enough.  Farewell.
Why?
They made mention that you were a grave robber.
Hmm.  I have other questions I would ask you.
I have heard enough.  Farewell.
You were a grave robber?
Hmm.  I have other questions I would ask you.
I have heard enough.  Farewell.
Permission?
Hmm.  I have other questions I would ask you.
I have heard enough.  Farewell.
Permission?
Hmm.  I have other questions I would ask you.
I have heard enough.  Farewell.
Robbery is robbery, and as a priest of Myrkul, I think you would be more respectful of the realm of the dead.
Hmm.  I have other questions I would ask you.
I have heard enough.  Farewell.
Hmm.  I have other questions I would ask you.
I have heard enough.  Farewell.
Other interests?
Hmm.  I have other questions I would ask you.
I have heard enough.  Farewell.
And yours aren't?
Hmm.  I have other questions I would ask you.
I have heard enough.  Farewell.
Hmm.  I have other questions I would ask you.
I have heard enough.  Farewell.
Shawford Crale has sent us here to see what you have learned from this goblin's corpse.
I had questions for you, Koluhm.
What are these bodies doing here again?
You told me why the soldier and goblins are here... but why is this townsperson here?
I have disturbed you.  I shall leave.
I think Shawford will need a little more than that.
Whatever you can tell us would be welcome.
My race knows something of the goblin tongue.  Speak what the goblin says, and I will see if I can translate.
My race knows a little of the goblin tongue.  Speak what the goblin says, and I will see if I can translate.
I picked up a little of the goblin tongue during my travels - speak what the goblin says, and I will see if I can translate.
Hmm.  Perhaps if you try to write down the words, you can send them to Shawford, and he can have someone translate them.
Excellent.  Thanks, Koluhm.
"Death," probably to Targos, if the accent is on the "hak."  Go on.
"We shall storm the walls, put your town to the sword..." etcetera, etcetera.  What else does it say?

He's saying something about a goblin shaman, or sorcerer, named "Caballus," leading the tribe to Targos... but it sounds like there's many tribes, and his tribe, the one attacking Targos, is just *one* of them. That's not good news.

Uh, he's saying, "just as we follow the three-headed beast, three of our mightiest (goblins, I think) shall strike at you," and the other words sound like names: Caballus, Ghotrag, and uh, "Vghotan," which means "Houndstooth," or "Dogstooth," or some stupid goblin approximation.
Hmmm.  Not exactly sure what he's saying here, but it sounds like he's listing off three names, or three leaders - perhaps other sorcerers.  Go on.
Hmmm.  Not exactly sure what he's saying here, but it's something about that goblin sorcerer.  The others could be other sorcerers.  Go on.
"As we strike at you from below, so shall we strike at your walls like the closing of a hand."
That means "attack... below" and something else, but I'm not sure what - he might be referring to the attack on the docks.  The dialect on these Northern goblins is difficult to get a handle on.
That means "attack... something," but I'm not sure what.  I'm not familiar with the dialect on these Northern goblins.
If those three names are the goblin leaders planning the next assault on Targos, then we know who to hit first... and who to tell the archers to aim for.  But what it said after that worries me.
If those three names are the goblin leaders planning the next assault on Targos, then we know who to hit first... and who to tell the archers to aim for.  This should prove useful.
Well, that name, "Caballus," is something, anyway.  I'll go tell Crale what we've learned.

It means they planned a simultaneous attack on Targos' walls with the attack on the docks - which means the walls could be attacked at any moment.  I must tell Shawford at once - and we might want to stock up on as many weapons and armor as we can before we return to the Palisade in case they attack while we're there.
You'll get paid, Koluhm.  Don't concern yourself with that.  I'll go report to Shawford now.
Have you been talking to him?  Is he at peace?
Have you been talking to him?  Is he at peace?
I see.  I had some other questions for you.
Very well, then.  Farewell, Koluhm.
Because it occurred to me, considering your shady past in Cormyr, you might have brought this body back here so you could question it about where it stashed its possessions.
I see.  I had some other questions for you.
Very well, then.  Farewell, Koluhm.
Lord Ulbrec may tolerate your presence, Koluhm, but he won't tolerate you looting the dead here in Targos.
Well, perhaps you better tell me what else you've learned from the dead here in Targos, and *then* I won't say anything to Lord Ulbrec about your grave robbery.
Very well.  Pleasure doing business with you, Koluhm.
See that you don't.  Farewell.
Very well.  Pleasure doing business with you, Koluhm.
I saw your "ward," Koluhm.  I am a priest, too, and your glyph was nothing more than scratching Myrkul's symbol on a wooden door.
Weeping spirit?
I see.  I had some other questions for you.
Very well, then.  Farewell, Koluhm.
It would indeed.  A ghost-touched bottle can prove quite valuable.
It would indeed.  This ghost-touched bottle could prove quite valuable.
Weeping spirit?
I see.  I had some other questions for you.
Very well, then.  Farewell, Koluhm.
Ghost-touched.  I mean, the water inside the bottle is useless, but the real enchantment is the bottle itself.  Cahl-Hyred didn't know what he had at first.

Yeah, it surprised me as well.  For a moment, I thought you had tried to dupe the innkeeper by paying him with a flask of water.  But a ghost-touched bottle is something else entirely - I imagine it's worth quite a bit of gold, isn't it?
What could such a bottle be used for?
I see.  I had some other questions for you.
Very well, then.  Farewell, Koluhm.
Indeed.  A ghost-touched bottle is quite valuable.
Indeed.  This ghost-touched bottle is quite valuable.
I see.  I had some other questions for you.
Very well, then.  Farewell, Koluhm.
